code.parms_list: Context >> a CommandBlockMorph ("script variables %scriptVars...") a VariableFrame {}
code.tempvars_delim: Context >> a CommandBlockMorph ("script variables %scriptVars...") a VariableFrame {}
code.doSetVar: Context >> a CommandBlockMorph ("script variables %scriptVars...") a VariableFrame {}

block-definition.comment: Give motors which are in a given group. You can know groups name with the block “all motors groups”

list.l: > is not in the aivaible groups of your robot :

block-definition.comment: Return a list with the name of every motors in the robot
Give the position of every motors. It is a shortcut to the block above. It is useful to make a snapshot of pose of the robot

Give the value of a register (position, speed, load, ... ) of one or many motors The “motor(s)” input can accept: - string of a motor name (e.g. m1) - string of many motors separated with spaces (e.g. m1 m2 m4) - a Snap! list of motors like the reporter block "$robot all motors" or the block “list”

inputs.input: present_positionposition=present_position speed=present_speed load (force)=present_load temperature=present_temperature voltage=present_voltage color

list.l: > is not in the available motors of your robot :

block-definition.comment: Return the index of a motor name in the "$robot all motors" block list

list.l: > is not in the aivaible motors of your robot :

block-definition.comment: Give the URL of the robot. For internal use only.

Put one or many motors in compliant or stiff mode. Motors are hand-drivable in compliant mode but must be in stiff mode to controlled with Snap!. The “motor(s)” input can accept: - string of a motor name (e.g. m1) - string of many motors separated with spaces (e.g. m1 m2 m4) - a Snap! list of motors like the reporter block "all motors" or the block “list”

block-definition.s: $robot set position(s) %'position' of motor(s) %'motors' in %'duration' seconds | wait ? %'wait'
block-definition.comment: Put one or many motors in a position (angle in degree) in a given time. The “motor(s)” input can accept: - string of a motor name (e.g. m1) - string of many motors separated with spaces (e.g. m1 m2 m4) - a Snap! list of motors like the reporter block "$robot all motors" or the block “list” “Wait” can be true or false. If it’s on True, the action will wait the end of the previous action. If it’s on False, then the action will proceed during the previous one

list.l: is not in the aivaible motors of your robot :

block-definition.comment: Restart the software inside the robot.
Give all records stored in this robot.
Take any number of input lists, and create a new list containing the items of the input lists. So APPEND [A B] [C D] where the [,,,] are lists reports the list [A B C D] not [[A B] [C D]].
Reports a new list containing the items of the input list, but in the opposite order.
Reports a new list whose items are the same as in the input list, except that if two or more equal items appear in the input list, only the last one is kept in the result.

Reports a sorted version of the list in its first input slot, using the comparison function in the second input slot. For a list of numbers, using < as the comparison function will sort from low to high; using > will sort from high to low.

Put the value to one register (position, speed, max torque, …) of one or many motors. The motor(s) input can accept : - string of a motor name - string of many motors separed with spaces - a Snap! list of motors like the reporter block "$robot all motors"

inputs.input: registerposition=goal_position speed=moving_speed max torque(%)=torque_limit compliancy(0 or 1)=compliant led

list.l: > is not in the aivaible motors of your robot :

block-definition.comment: Give the list of all attached/ running behaviours .

Play the movement of a previous recorded move. The <record_name> input is the name of a .record filename which should be in the same directory where you started the web server (with the command "$robot-snap $robot-ergo" for example). You can change the play speed with the <speed> input. This block can be nested in the “concurrent/sequential” block.

custom-block.s: $robot play move %s in reverse | speed x %n

block.comment: ugly wait to stop feature. TODO : change with a looking at running primitive

list.l: > is not is the avaible records (look at the block $robot all records to see all recorded moves)

block-definition.comment: All blocks in input are run one after each other. You can use this block to play concurrently many sequently move.
All reports input are run simultaneously. You can use this block to play concurrently many recorded move.
Takes any number of numbers as inputs (use the left and right arrowheads to adjust the number of input slots) and reports the result of adding them all, so ISUM (4) (100) (8)) reports 112.
Takes any number of numbers as inputs (use the left and right arrowheads to adjust the number of input slots) and reports the result of multiplying them all, so (PRODUCT (4) (100) (8)) reports 3200.

Takes any number of Boolean (true/false) inputs (use the left and right arrowheads to adjust the number of input slots) and reports TRUE only if all of the inputs are TRUE, otherwise FALSE. Like AND but for multiple inputs.
Takes any number of Boolean (true/false) inputs (use the left and right arrowheads to adjust the number of input slots) and reports TRUE if at least one input is TRUE, otherwise FALSE.

block-definition.s: $robot create & start record move %'record_name' with motor(s) %'motors input'
block-definition.comment: Create and start a movement recorded by demonstration to the given motors. The <record_name> input is used to store the recorded move. The move is stored in the directory where you started the web server (with the command "$robot-snap $robot-ergo" for example), and can be replayed even if you close Snap! The motor(s) input can accept : - string of a motor name - string of many motors separed with spaces - a Snap! list of motors like the reporter block "$robot all motors" If the motor(s) input is empty, all motors will be recorded.

custom-block.l: Input error, record name must not be empty
Input error, you should look at help (right click on the bock)

block.comment: Set all aliases here for optimisation issues

list.l: does not exist in your robot.

block-definition.comment: Stop recording the desired move record. Be careful, you must have previously defined a move record with the "create move ... with motor(s) ..." block
Stop a movement that is being played
Works as the map block (see map help), but it proceeds iterations concurently.
Play movements at the same time (can be nested to concurrent block). Inputs can be : - move name (string) - any reporter block, like sequential or play sequentially

custom-block.l: Input is not valid. See help (right click on the block)

scripts.comment: TODO : understand why a sequential input blocks return items on a list rather than separated with whitespace

block-definition.comment: Play movements following in order (can be nested to sequential block). Inputs can be : - move name (string) - any reporter block, like sequential or play sequentially

custom-block.l: Input is not valid. See help (right click on the block)

block-definition.comment: Return a list of all aliases. Alias is a keyword for representing many motors at once.
Return a sublist which contains items in the interval of 2 input numbers. Original list is not modified.

block-definition.s: $robot play move %'record_name' in reverse | speed x %'speed'
block-definition.comment: Play in reverse the movement of a previous recorded move. The <record_name> input is the name of a .record filename which should be in the same directory where you started the web server (with the command "$robot-snap $robot-ergo" for example). You can change the play speed with the <speed> input.

block.comment: ugly wait to stop feature. TODO : change with a looking at running primitive

list.l: > is not is the avaible records (look at the block $robot all records to see all recorded moves)

block-definition.comment: Click on this block to verify that you are connected to your robot

block.l: You may have connection troubles. Check the host variable

block-definition.comment: Return the index of a item in a list
Start/ Stop/ Pause/ Resume an integrated behaviour of the robot. It can be a position, a movement, a sensorimotor loop, high level camera feature.

list.l: > is not in the aivaible primitives of your robot :

block-definition.comment: Get all methods or functions which are runnable in a behavior. It is an advanced block.

list.l: > is not in the aivaible primitives of your robot :

block-definition.comment: Set robot host to … The host input can accept : - robot_name.local (e.g. : poppy.local if your robot’s name is poppy) Or the IP address (e.g. 123.124.145.176) This block allows you to connect Snap! to your robot

Play the movement of a previous recorded move. The <record_name> input is the name of a .record filename which should be in the same directory where you started the web server (with the command "$robot-snap $robot-ergo" for example). You can change the play speed with the <speed> input.

custom-block.s: $robot play move %s in reverse | speed x %n

block-definition.s: $robot set color leds of motor(s) %'motor_name' in %'color'
block-definition.comment: Activate/deactivate color leds of motors and choose the color of your choice. The “motor(s)” input can accept: - string of a motor name (e.g. m1) - string of many motors separated with spaces (e.g. m1 m2 m4) - a Snap! list of motors like the reporter block "$robot all motors" or the block “list

inputs.input: offoff red green yellow blue pink cyan white

block.l: off red green yellow blue pink cyan white

block-definition.comment: Return a boolean (true/false) depending if the selected card is detected by the camera of the robot.
